ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would summarize it as a course open to anyone who is interested in the interactions between authority, history, and art and architecture.

The course explores broad concepts in Japanese architecture and art in relation to the country's vast history as well as with regard to cognitive and humanist approaches to art, making it an accessible graduate seminar to students of different disciplines and individual strengths.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Professor Yiengpruksawan's approach to her material has made me rethink preconceived notions about my own discipline and topics.

The course reminded me that asking questions that lay outside of strict art historical methodology is extremely very fruitful in the research process. This, I believe, is essential in the field, especially when developing research approaches for term papers and ultimately, the dissertation.

It gave me architectural evidence to support some of my theories, which need supplementation because there isn't enough literature. It has helped me understand the craftsmanship and construction of many of the sites I have visited in Japan, and I am grateful to finally be able to appreciate them more. At least now I know where to begin to look in terms of gathering more information for analysis.
